entry.title: SAP BTP - APIM - Demystified: Designing a Single API Proxy with Dynamic Routing for Multiple Targets
entry.content:
Introduction

In modern enterprise landscapes, APIs are no longer simple pass-through interfaces; they are strategic assets that must support multiple backends, environment segregation, multi-tenant scenarios, and dynamic routing—all while remaining secure, observable, and maintainable.

Within the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP API Management plays a critical role as the security and governance layer for backend systems like SAP Integration Suite (CPI), S/4HANA, ECC, Fieldglass, Concur, and various external applications.

In this blog, I present a common enterprise requirement: designing a single security layer that acts as a shield for SAP CPI, handling access control, host protection, and traffic governance. I will demonstrate how to build a single API Proxy with dynamic routing capabilities, allowing multiple iFlow endpoints to be managed through one centralized entry point.

This approach eliminates the need for hundreds of individual proxies, keeps the APIM cockpit organized, and significantly simplifies monitoring. Whether you are a beginner following the step-by-step visuals or a senior consultant jumping straight to the "Checkmate" strategy at the end, this guide is designed for all levels of expertise.

🗝️ The check-mate secret will be revealed at the end.🗝️

To illustrate the introduction, please check the image below:

Figure 1 - Integration Prespective

Summary of the image:

  1. Consumer → calls → API Proxy (in SAP APIM)
  2. API Proxy (Apply Policies) → forwards to → API Provider (SAP CPI- Multiples Iflows from the SAP package)
  3. SAP CPI  → processes logic → Any Backend ( SAP on-prem/SAP on-cloud/External App)

Let’s move forward together and break down the concepts step by step.

Before we get hands-on, let’s take a short theoretical detour to clearly understand what each object is responsible for.

What is an API Proxy ?

Think of the proxy as a Security and Governance Layer. While the backend provides the data, the proxy provides

  • Security: Enforces OAuth, Basic Authentication, API Keys Header, or SQL injection protection.
  • Traffic Control: Sets rate limits (e.g., 100 calls per minute) to protect your backend from crashing.
  • Transformation: Converts data formats (e.g., SOAP to REST or XML to JSON) without changing the backend code.
  • Analytics: Tracks who is using the API and how often.

What is API provider ?

An API Provider is a centralized configuration in SAP APIM that defines the connection details, authentication, and location of a backend system, such as SAP S/4HANA or SAP CPI.

Instead of hard-coding URLs into every individual proxy, you create a Provider once to act as a reusable gateway to that system’s entire service catalog.

This "clean" approach allows you to automatically discover services and update backend settings in one single place without breaking your existing API proxies.

Can SAP CPI be an API Provider?

Yes, absolutely. In fact, this is a very common "best practice" in the SAP Integration Suite.

  • SAP CPI (Cloud Integration) is the Execution Engine: It handles the complex logic, data mapping, and connecting to multiple systems.
  • SAP APIM is the Governance Layer: It handles the exposure of that CPI flow to the outside world

From Concept to Implementation

We’ve talked the talk — now it’s time to make these APIs working.

Our Mission Together

Build a Multi-Target Mega-Proxy:

  • One front door (API Proxy)
  • Smart enough to check the visitor’s “ID” (headers, basic authentication, mask host)
  • Routes requests dynamically to different CPI iFlows based on the HTTP path

I'm going to cross together with you in phases:

  • Phase 1: The "Secret Agents" (Setting up Providers)
  • Phase 2: The "Master Architect" (Creating the Proxy)
  • Phase 3: The "Split Personality" (Adding the Second Target)
  • Phase 4: The "The Routing Gate for Heaven" (Time to setup the routing mechanism)
  • Phase 5: The "Dangerous Security Zone" (Applying the Shields)

Phase 1: The "Secret Agents" (Setting up Providers)

Before we build the bridge, we need to know where the islands are.

  1. Go to your APIM Portal and hit the Configure icon (the little gears).

  2. Create your first Agent (API Provider): Let’s call it SAPCPI.

    1.  

      Type: Choose Cloud Integration.
    2. Host: Paste your CPI tenant runtime URL (leave out the https:// - just the hostname).

  3. Save & Test: Click that "Test Connection" button. If it turns green, you’re a genius. If it turns yellow HTTP 400, you as CPI developer know the reason, the connection is working don't worry.

Figure 2 - API Provider - SAP CPI Configured

Phase 2: The "Master Architect" (Creating the Proxy)

Now, let's build the Proxy that will rule them all, as you can see API proxy can be generated with API provider, API Proxy or URL. To keep very organized and clean governance, use API Provider or API proxy as clone the URL I don't recommend, just for POC that's ok.

  1. Develop → APIs → Create
  2. The Choice: Select API Provider.
    Pick SAPCPI. 
  3. URL: /
  4. The Name (My recommendation, use the same CPI Package name as reference): Call it PackageSAPSCNBlog.
  5. Host alias: <hostname.your.sap.apim>
  6. API base path ( you can add what ever you want, just as suggestion): /sapcpi/

Figure 3 - Creating the proxy with API provider

Phase 3: The "Split Personality" (Adding the Second Target)

By default, your proxy only knows about CPI. Let's give it a second destination.

  1. Open your new Proxy and go to the Target Endpoints tab.
  2. Click the + (Add) button.
  3. Name it (I recomend the name of Iflow to mantain organized): .<IflowName>

  4. The Magic Link: provide the path generate in SAP CPI, in this case /http/cpi/IflowA.

    • Now your Proxy has two exits, but it doesn't know which one to use yet!

Figure 3 - Create TargetEndpoint

After you generate the target endpoints, you are going to see something like this:

Figure 4 - Multiples Target Endpoints

Phase 4: The "The Routing Gate for Heaven (Time to setup the routing mechanism)

  1. The Choice: ProxyEndPoint
  2. Add the routing rules based on path of SAP CPI endpoint sample based on this blog
    1. IflowA -  proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowA"
    2. IflowB  - proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowB"
    3. IflowC - proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowC"
    4. IflowD -  proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowD"
    5. IflowE -   proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowE"
    6.  
  3. In this point you can delete the router - default

Figure 5 - Multiples Variable Runtime - proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath

Phase 5: The "Dangerous Security Zone" (Applying the Shields - Policies)

To solve the Chess Puzzle of APIM, you have to understand the "Timeline" of a request. A single API call is like a round-trip train journey. The request goes in through the Proxy and out to the Target, then the response comes back from the Target and out through the Proxy.

The PreFlow and PostFlow are the "Stations" where you can plug in your policies.

Proxy Endpoint (The Front Door)

This is where the client (Postman, Mobile App) interacts with APIM.

  • PreFlow: This happens first. It is the best place for Security (API Key, OAuth) and Spike Arrest. If the "visitor" is dangerous, you kick them out here before they waste any more of your system's energy.
  • PostFlow: This happens last, just before the response is sent back to the client. It’s perfect for Logging or clean-up.

Target Endpoint (The Back Door)

This is where APIM interacts with your backend.

  • PreFlow: This happens right before the request hits your backend. It is the best place for Transformation (adding a specific header the backend needs) or URL Rewriting.
  • PostFlow: This happens right after the backend responds but before it goes back to the Proxy. This is where you might Format JSON or remove sensitive backend headers.

So in the Proxy Endpoint - Preflow I added some security and custom messages replay as you can see in the image below:

Figure 6 - Security Policies - Proxy Endpoing Pre-flow

These are basic policies; for your project, you could add Spike Arrest, OAuth2 validation, and Credential Buffering, but since the focus isn't on complex policies right now, let's stick to the foundational ones.

  1. Step 1: Java script check header
  2. Step 2: Fault custom message response
  3. Step 3: Standard Basic Authentication - Here you need to change the XML from encode to decode
  4. Step 4:Java script security header
  5. Step5: Java script check credentials
  6. Step 6: Fault custom message response - In case of user/pass is empty or different from API Provider - SAP CPI
  7. Step 7: Java Script Set host

In case that you want custom the Fault message, because the standard one it's really technical and if you create something custom will helps more your consumers.

Figure 7 - Custom replay Fault exception

  • Step 2: Fault custom message response
<RaiseFault continueOnError="false"
            enabled="true"
            xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">

    <FaultResponse>
        <Set>
            <Headers>
                <Header name="Content-Type">application/json</Header>
            </Headers>

            <Payload contentType="application/json">
            {
              "Error": "HTTP 500 - Internal Server Error",
              "Detail": "(Basic Authtentication - User/Password) is required to access this API."
            }
            </Payload>

            <StatusCode>500</StatusCode>
            <ReasonPhrase>Internal Server Error</ReasonPhrase>
        </Set>
    </FaultResponse>

    <IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>

</RaiseFault>
  • Step 6: Fault custom message response - In case of user/pass is empty or different from API Provider - SAP CPI
<RaiseFault continueOnError="false" enabled="true"
            xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">

    <FaultResponse>
        <Set>
            <Headers>
                <Header name="Content-Type">application/json</Header>
            </Headers>
            <Payload contentType="application/json">
            {
              "error": "HTTP 401 Unauthorized",
              "message": "Invalid username or password.The credentials can not be empty value."
            }
            </Payload>
            <StatusCode>401</StatusCode>
            <ReasonPhrase>Unauthorized</ReasonPhrase>
        </Set>
    </FaultResponse>
</RaiseFault>

Full java script - Main.js - I decide create in this way to also keep organized and centralized all functions in one place instead of create one java script per function.

//Check the Check Header
function handleSecurityHeader() {
var authHeader = context.getVariable("request.header.Authorization");

if (!authHeader) {
    context.setVariable("auth.header.missing", true);
} else {
    context.setVariable("auth.header.missing", false);
}
}

//Validation of user/pass
function handleCredentialCheck() {

var user = context.getVariable("basic.username");
var pass = context.getVariable("basic.password");

// DEBUG
context.setVariable("username", user);
context.setVariable("pass", pass);

if (!user || !pass) {
    context.setVariable("auth.failed", true);
} else if (user !== "<SAP CPI USER PROVIDED>" || pass !== "<SAP CPI PASSWORD PROVIDED>") {
    context.setVariable("auth.failed", false);
}
}

//Mask Address
function handleResponseMasking() {
    var rc = context.getVariable("response.content");
    
    if (rc) {
        var targetHost = context.getVariable("target.host");
        var proxyHost = context.getVariable("proxy.host");
        var targetBase = context.getVariable("target.basepath");
        var proxyBase = context.getVariable("proxy.basepath");

        var maskedResponse = rc;

        // Mask the Hostname
        if (targetHost && proxyHost) {
            // 'g' means global (replace all), 'i' means case-insensitive
            var hostRegex = new RegExp(targetHost.toString(), 'gi');
            maskedResponse = maskedResponse.replace(hostRegex, proxyHost.toString());
        }

        // Mask the Base Path
        if (targetBase && proxyBase) {
            var baseRegex = new RegExp(targetBase.toString(), 'gi');
            maskedResponse = maskedResponse.replace(baseRegex, proxyBase.toString());
        } 

        // Update the response content and the custom variable
        context.setVariable("target.host",maskedResponse)
        context.setVariable("response.content", maskedResponse);
        context.setVariable("masked.targeturl", maskedResponse);
    }
}

//Routing mechanism
function RoutingCpiEndpoint() {
    
var suffix = context.getVariable("proxy.pathsuffix");
if (suffix == null) {
    suffix = "";
}

var targetBase = "<SAP CPI ADDRESS>";

// Use the + operator for compatibility
var finalUrl = targetBase.toString() + suffix.toString();

// Set it back to a context variable so the target can use it
context.setVariable("target.url", finalUrl);

}

 //Sets the proxy host in the proxyendpoint preflow so that it can be used later on
function setProxyHost(){
  var host = context.proxyRequest.headers['host'];
  context.setVariable("apim.proxyHost", host);
}

The visual with this organization, the fact you also will create the Main.js, you need to generate the others java scripts, as suggestion create with name convention JS-Exe(function)

Figure 8 - JavaScript Main and Java Script excetion

After that you can click in Java script in the Policy and add in the steps, but how to configure the XML ? Check below:

<IncludeURL>jsc://JS-Main.js</IncludeURL> - Include the JS-Main.js
<ResourceURL>jsc://JS-ExehandleSecurityHeader.js</ResourceURL> - Include the Java Script with function only

If APIM is the "Intelligent Front Door" of your building, then SAP CPI (Cloud Integration) is the "Kitchen" where the real magic (and sometimes the mess) happens.

While APIM is outside checking IDs and looking cool, CPI is in the back wearing an apron, chopping data into pieces, and trying to make sure the S/4HANA "steak" is served exactly the way the client's "mobile app" wants it. 😂🤣

The SAP CPI perspective, a package represents ( Product ) inside de product contains the services A,B,C,D,E via API as you can see below:

Figure 9 - SAP CPI Packages and Iflows

  1. IflowA -  https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowA
  2. IflowB  - https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowB
  3. IflowC - https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowC
  4. IflowD -  https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowD
  5. IflowE -  https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowE

Ok, you already setup the API Management, Endpoint, Add routing, Policies, generate SAP CPI package, Iflows, deploy those iflow now we are ready to test ? 

I followed the SAP Help guide step by step SAP Help enable-dynamic-routing. I was ready for glory.

Test Phase:

Take the endpoint generated in API management concatenate with the respective path of the iflow that must be called and that's it, use the post man as source for test proposal.

  • SAP APIM: https://<yourinstance>apimanagement.eu20.hana.ondemand.com/sapcpi/
  • SAP CPI:https://<cpihostnamefrom API provide>/http/cpi/IflowA
  • EndURL:https://<yourinstance>apimanagement.eu20.hana.ondemand.com/sapcpi/http/cpi/IflowA

Uhu, let's go postman !!!

Figure 10 - HTTP 404

Instead, I was met with the cold, hard stare of a 404 – Not Found.

Is the documentation wrong? ❌
Is the API broken? ❌

We have simply entered the “chess puzzle” phase of dynamic routing. Don’t worry — we are in this together.

The Final Move: A 'Checkmate' Strategy for Polishing Your API Proxy - The Secret.

In the picture below I'm representing all the topics that we already discuss, if you are tunned, you could see the magic inside the java script JS-Main.js, if not you will see now in the steps below.

Figure 11 - Each endpoint contains Target Endpoint Policy that must be configured with java script in inbound message

The SAP APIM management it self in case of Proxy with API Provider is not able to concatenate automatic the hostname of API provider with the specific PATH URL from the back end system in case of multiple routing mechanism based on path, for it you must use the Java script, that reads the variables in runtime and do this activity, without it always will generate HTTP 404.

In case that you create the API Proxy for URL, yes, he can route automatic you declarator the endpoint, the same for API Provider only with default setup, but with multiple routing, no impossible, I did all possibilities that you can image.

Basically in all target points, in the target endpoint police, the pre-flow, you must add this function:

//Routing mechanism
function RoutingCpiEndpoint() {
    
var suffix = context.getVariable("proxy.pathsuffix");
if (suffix == null) {
    suffix = "";
}

var targetBase = "<SAP CPI ADDRESS>";

// Use the + operator for compatibility
var finalUrl = targetBase.toString() + suffix.toString();

// Set it back to a context variable so the target can use it
context.setVariable("target.url", finalUrl);

}

Figure 12 - Adding the magic java script in the Target End point - Pre flow - Incoming Message of each Iflow

After that you can see the debug in SAP APIM:

Figure 13 - Debug all policies - Proxy Endpoint - Target Endpoint - Pre/Pos Flow

Variables from the debug:

Figure 14 - Debug variables runtime

Postman test:

Figure 15 - Postman

By adopting this design, you eliminate the need to build individual proxies for every endpoint. This centralizes policy management, keeps the SAP API Management cockpit clutter-free, and creates a highly organized, scalable architecture that is significantly easier to govern.

Figure 16 - One API proxy vs Individual Proxy

The Consumer Perspective:

By adopting this approach, SAP API Management (APIM) serves as a centralized "Mega Proxy." This allows for the reutilization of a single entry point to deliver multiple services to various consumers. These consumers can access diverse SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) APIs, which handle data mapping, transformation, and complex business logic for back-end systems like SAP ECC, SAP S/4HANA (both on-premise and cloud), and other third-party services.

In this architecture, SAP APIM acts as a robust API Firewall. No direct CPI endpoints are exposed to the consumer, effectively shielding your landscape from cyberattacks and unauthorized access.

Figure 17 - Consumer perspective

The Final Whistle: Game, Set, Match.

And there you have it! You’ve just turned a potential "Proxy Nightmare" into a sleek, centralized, routing machine.

While others are out there manually building their 157th individual proxy (and crying into their coffee), you’re sitting back with a clean cockpit, a single "Mega-Proxy," and a architecture that actually scales. We took the 404 monster, hit it with a bit of JavaScript magic, and walked away with the Checkmate.

Go ahead, deploy it, and watch your monitoring dashboard finally look like it was managed by a pro. Just don't tell everyone the "Checkmate" secret at once—let them wonder how you became an APIM wizard overnight.

Kind Regards,

Viana

References about topic:

In this blog, the author presents a different approach using query parameters, and while it is a valid perspective, I found it difficult to identify how to call different endpoints specifically, also editing manually the xml's, not sure if in 2021 the APIM version required such manual intervention..

SAPAPIM - Guide to create single API Proxy with multiple Target End Point and capability to change the target URI during execution

entry.title: Re: Hyper-V virtualization is not supported for SAP syste...
entry.content:
The SAP  hardware key was years ago also on AIX / PowerVM an HA and/or migration a "problem".

At that time we had to  create a license for every PowerVM-"rack" and we had now problems with changing the "motherships".
Using encapsuled virtualisation helped, so that changing the hosts was on application layer transparent.

So, if the changing hosts / "motherships" is still a topic for you, just create additional license keys and install them to the database amd/or appl server(s).  It only costs your time generating, downloading and installing all those additional keys.
SAP does not charge you extra. 😉

entry.title: Using SCIM API for User & Member List management in SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition
entry.content:
If you’ve worked with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, you might have come across the SCIM 2.0–compliant API. This API is designed for managing users and member lists, following the common specification.
Now, SCIM is a broad standard with many optional elements. SAP’s implementation focuses on the essentials, so not every optional detail is covered - but everything you need for user and list management is there. 

Where does this SCIM API fit in the Work Zone landscape?

The SCIM API is utilized by SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) to handle User and List/Group management for the Digital Workplace Service component of both following variants- Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition and SuccessFactors Work Zone. 

If you’re configuring IPS for Work Zone user provisioning, you’ll find detailed guidance in our help documentation.

  • Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition
  • SuccessFactors Work Zone

IPS should always be used as the primary means of User provisioning & management in Work Zone.
But what if you want to go hands-on with the API yourself, for small scale user data adjustment or simply to check data? That is what we are going to cover in this blog.

Important resource to go through before attempting to use the API-> Using the SCIM API | SAP Help Portal

Key elements needed to use the SCIM API for User & List Management-

  • Digital Workplace/Jam URL-> Administration Console -> Overview -> Custom Domain URL (for Jam instances not using custom domain, just the regular JAM DC URL- jamX.sapjam.com)
  • SCIM API Client Key: Administration Console -> OAuth Clients -> SCIM Client (will have integration URL as  http://www.simplecloud.info) -> Key
  • SCIM API Client Secret: Administration Console -> OAuth Clients -> SCIM Client (will have integration URL as  http://www.simplecloud.info) -> Secret
  • SCIM API Token URL-> https://<Digital Workplace/Jam URL>/api/v1/auth/token

 

[A] GETTING THE SCIM API ACCESS TOKEN

First step in using SCIM API is getting the access token.

Using any suitable tool (like Postman) POST call needs to be made to the SCIM API Token URL, passing the SCIM API Client Key & Secret. This will return the Access token.

Steps (Postman tool used for this example):

  1. Method: POST
  2. URL: https://<Digital Workplace/Jam URL>/api/v1/auth/token
  3. In the request Body:
    • client_id: < SCIM API Client Key >
    • client_secret: < SCIM API Client Secret >
    • grant_type: client_credentials
  4. Here is what the API call looks like in Postman-
  5. After making the call by hitting “Send”, access token returned in Response-

 

[B] USING THE SCIM API TO VIEW, UPDATE OR DELETE USER

User management via SCIM API will require-

  • Access Token: from section [A] steps
  • User_UUID: Can be grabbed from the browser URL of any user profile page in Work Zone. The alphanumeric identifier at the end of the URL will be the UUid.
    • Example URL: https://swzhrcpsdemo.workzonehr.cfapps.sap.hana.ondemand.com/site#workzone-profile?sap-app-origin-hint=&/profile/wall/QljGDtyuvpRDK7epwV0GiU
    • QljGDtyuvpRDK7epwV0GiUis the UUid.
  • SCIM User API URL: https://<Digital Workplace/Jam URL>/api/v1/scim/Users/<user_uuid>

Using the above User API URL and the User UUid,

  • GET calls can be made to view user data.
  • PUT calls can be made to update user data.
  • DELETE calls can be made to delete any user from Work Zone database.

 

[B.1] TO VIEW ANY USER RECORD

  1. Method: GET
  2. URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Users/<user_uuid>
  3. In the request Header,
    •      Authorization = OAuth <access_token>
  4. Here is what the API call looks like in Postman for one example User UUid:
  5. And the Response after hitting “Send”

[B.2] TO UPDATE ANY USER RECORD

  1. Method: PUT
  2. URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Users/<user_uuid>
  3. In the request Header,
    •      Authorization = OAuth <access_token>
  4. In the request Body, user data request payload in DWS/Jam SCIM format.
  5. Here is what the API call looks like for one example User-
  6. If we submit this API call by hitting “Send”, the user will get updated with the payload data from the request body.

[B.3] TO DELETE ANY USER RECORD

  1. Method: DELETE
  2. URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Users/<user_uuid>
  3. In the request Header,
    •      Authorization = OAuth <access_token>
  4. Here is what the API call looks like for one example User UUid:
  5. If we submit this API call by hitting “Send”, the user will get deleted

 

[C] USING THE SCIM API TO VIEW OR DELETE MEMBER LIST

  • Access Token: from section [A] steps
  • list_name: Name of the List
  • list_id: Has to be retrieved via API call, searching with List Name.
  • SCIM List API URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Groups/<list_id>

[C.1] GET THE LIST ID

To search List ID for any List, same steps to be followed as viewing users, [B.1] section above, only changing to API endpoint /Groups:

  • URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Groups? filter=displayName eq "<list_name>"

The API response will have the List ID in “id” field

[C.2] VIEW A LIST

To view SCIM data for any List, same steps to be followed as viewing users, [B.1] section above, only changing to API endpoint /Groups:

  • URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Groups/< list_id >

[C.3] DELETE A LIST

To delete any List, same steps to be followed as deleting users, [B.3] section above, only changing to API endpoint /Groups:

  • URL: https://< Digital Workplace/Jam URL >/api/v1/scim/Groups/< list_id >

entry.title: Re: CBO Transported to TEST but Not Available in Business...
entry.content:
Dear @MohamedKharbouch,

Question 1. Is this behavior expected?

It can be expected if you transported only the CBO definition but not the related Custom Catalog Extension / IAM / launchpad artifacts. SAP explicitly calls out that when a CBO-generated app isn’t available in the target tenant, common causes are:

  • the app wasn’t added to a business catalog via Custom Catalog Extensions or
  • the custom catalog extension wasn’t transported even though the CBO was

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2544054

Question 2. Do business catalog assignments have to be re-done manually per system?

No, not if you transport the right artifacts. The assignment that matters for Key User Extensibility is typically stored as a Custom Catalog Extensions for CBOs you’ll often see an entry with the _SCBO suffix. SAP guidance for CBO access is to maintain it in Custom Catalog Extensions and publish it

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2687424

If that Custom Catalog Extensions and related IAM objects wasn’t included in the export/import then yes you would end up re-doing it manually in TEST but that’s more of a workaround than a best practice

Question 3. Recommended sequence

In DEV:

1. CBO is Published and Generated UI exists if that’s what you want to expose

2. Go to Custom Catalog Extensions:

    • Search your CBO and open the entry with suffix _SCBO
    • Add the required standard business catalog
    • Publish and run Check
      IMPORTANT: SAP notes exports can fail / behave inconsistently if the catalog extension or assigned catalogs are not published

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3407810

3. When building the Software Collection ensure you include not only the CBO but also the catalog/IAM artifacts

SAP even lists the typical missing transport objects for custom app not visible after transport scenarios:

  • Business catalog (SIA6)
  • IAM app (SIA1)
  • Business Catalog Assignment (SIA7)
  • Launchpad Descriptor Item (UIAD)

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3635471

In TEST:

  1. Open Custom Catalog Extensions and search for the YY1_<…>_SCBO entry:
    • If it’s there but shows Unpublished, publish it and re-check
  2. Be aware publishing can be asynchronous after import. SAP explicitly mentions cases where it’s transported but not finished publishing yet and the fix is to wait until status becomes Published

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2788116

3. If the _SCBO entry is missing entirely that strongly indicates the catalog extension and/or related IAM objects simply weren’t transported, re-export/re-import with the missing objects included

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2544054

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: How to Automatically Delete EC Alerts when Contract End Date is Emptied?
entry.content: @ gemmaaquiatan, were you able to find a solution to handle the old alert when the contract end date is emptied/set to null? We have the same issue and entering 9999-12-31 as the new contract end date isn't ideal, nor manually deleting from Manage Alerts & Notifications. Thanks.
